There were two main styles: the gable hood, which was popular in England and had a quasi-pentagonal, angled shape that covered most of the head down to the ears; and the French hood, which was more popular in France and curved backward atop the head to expose much of the hair. The French hood later subsumed the gable hood in popularity, even in England. Hoods are extremely common in art from the era, especially in portraits of Henry VIII’s wives and the other Tudor queens.

The men’s wig (1650s to 1800s) The wig became a core element of men’s European fashion in the 1620s when France’s Louis XIII went bald young and began wearing wigs, a practice his son Louis XIV continued. Britain resisted this continental fashion until the Restoration, when Charles II (who had been in exile in France) proudly wore wigs at court. These wigs, while massive and wide, originally mimicked natural hair color; by the 1750s, the standard male wig was less elaborate, often had a short ponytail-like queue, and was white to better match the white powder used to maintain it. The male wig fell out of fashion in the 1800s for two chief reasons: the first was a severe English tax on wig powder passed in 1795; the second was that wigs, a symbol of royalty, became distasteful amidst the rise of populist republics in America and France. (This, however, did not stop early American presidents such as John Adams and James Monroe from wearing the wigs that had been fashionable when they were younger.)

The kilt (mid-17th century onward) Contrary to common depictions in film and television, the Scottish kilt did not exist in the medieval era. The great kilt (an immense garment that wraps around the waist and is then wrapped up around the shoulder) came about first, with the more recognizable small kilt (waist-only) arising in the early 18th century. The practice of wearing the kilt in Scotland caught on immediately, and it became so quickly and deeply tied to Scottish identity that, after Britain crushed the nationalist Jacobite Rising of 1745, the kilt was banned under the Dress Act for four decades. The kilt was revived in the 1820s when the fashion-obsessed George IV wore one in public, and it became heavily romanticized. It was not until this later 19th-century revival that clan-specific tartan patterns developed and myths arose regarding who was “allowed” to wear certain tartans.

Crinoline and hoop skirts (mid-19th century) Structured ladies’ skirts had always been around to some extent (such as the wide-hipped dresses and panniers of the Rococo era), but in the 1840s, European women began layering underskirt upon underskirt beneath dresses to create a slim-waisted, bell-shaped silhouette called “crinoline” (after crin, a common fabric in the underskirts). Crinoline exploded in popularity in 1856 with the patenting of cage crinoline, a rigid, light, lattice-like underskirt; this did away with the heavy multi-layering method, allowing crinoline to be affordable for all social classes and resulting in super-wide hoop skirts. Crinoline could sometimes prove hazardous: hundreds of women died from their hoop skirts draping into fireplaces and catching fire. Crinoline is now emblematic of the early Victorian era (and of Antebellum society in the U.S.). In the 1870s crinoline and hoop skirts faded in popularity but lived on as the vastly minimized bustle, which extended only from the backside.

The Victorian corset (mid-19th century to early 20th century) Like structured skirts, corsets in some form were part of women’s dress for centuries, but beginning in the 1820s, tight-laced corsets became near-compulsory in women’s fashion. By the mid-19th century, after crinoline fell from fashion, the “wasp waist” was seen as ideal (though the oft-cited ideal of the 18″ waistline may be an exaggeration or myth), and it was achieved through very tight cinching of whalebone corsets. From its outset, tight-laced corsetry was known to be unhealthy, and many newspapers of the time ran articles denouncing its excesses. Still, the corset remained ubiquitous at the turn of the century, when it was core to the all-American “Gibson girl” ideal. It was only the wholesale social changes brought on by World War I that caused the corset to vanish from everyday dress.

Reform dress (mid-19th century) The controversy over corsets coincided with the first wave of feminism in Europe, and many activists proposed alternatives that were collectively called “reform dress.” In the 1850s, Amelia Jenks Bloomer, an American feminist, advocated for a loose feminine trouser suit known by her name—“bloomers” or the “bloomer suit”—but constant ridicule led to its abandonment. In that same decade, “Artistic Dress” arose among followers of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, who favored looser, medieval-inspired garb. Reform dress was typically viewed as extreme, as it played into growing worries about women’s emancipation thanks to industrialization and the bicycle. Ultimately, outside of the emancipation waist (a bodice undergarment of strong fabric), no element of “reform dress” achieved anything more than fleeting use outside activist circles.

Flapper fashion (1910s–1930) The term “flapper” originally referred to a vivacious teenage girl, but by the late 1910s it came to identify impetuous young women who flouted long-standing gender norms. In particular, the “flapper” wore short skirts (above the knee), cut her hair short into a bob, and enjoyed conventionally masculine pastimes, which at the time were as innocuous as driving a car, smoking, and drinking hard liquor. The aesthetics of jazz clubs also played into the flapper image, as did contemporary mainstream fashion items such as cloche hats (bell-shaped hats that cup close to the face) and heavy use of rouge, eyeliner, and lipstick. Though it had analogs in Europe and the U.K., the flapper was chiefly an American phenomenon closely tied to the prosperity of the Roaring Twenties; its appeal evaporated amidst the austerity of the Great Depression.

The bikini (1946 to today) The bikini debuted at a time when women’s swimsuits were usually a generous top paired with high-rise shorts that bared some midriff. Designed by Louis Reard for a swimsuit fashion show in Paris in 1946, the bikini was an instant controversy, as it was little more than string briefs paired with a bra. Reard named the garment after the Bikini Atoll, where the U.S. held atomic bomb tests less than a week prior. The bikini was a hit at the Paris show but proved too shocking to mainstream culture. In the 1950s, it was often worn by movie stars such as Marilyn Monroe or fashion models as publicity stunts; it was not until 1962, when Ursula Andress wore an iconic white bikini in a scene in the first James Bond film, Dr. No, that the bikini gained mainstream acceptance.

title: Works By Leonardo Da Vinci
content:
Leonardo’s Left Angel in Verrocchio’s The Baptism of Christ (ca. 1475) is among the earliest works attributed to the Renaissance master. Leonardo was an apprentice in the workshop of the Florentine artist Andrea del Verrocchio, and was asked to add the angel to Verrocchio’s painting of The Baptism of Christ, as it was common practice for students to complete less important sections of a teacher’s paintings. The contrast between the subtlety of color and minute detail in Leonardo’s angel, as compared to the other figures, is striking; scholars also speculate Leonardo painted much of the background, as it—like the angel—was done in oil rather than tempera. According to a fanciful (but almost certainly apocryphal) story from biographer Giorgio Vasari, after seeing Leonardo’s angel, Verrocchio snapped his paintbrushes in half and swore off painting for the rest of his life.

The Annunciation (ca. 1475) is Leonardo’s earliest major complete canvas, and was completed—like his angel—while he was still a student in Verrocchio’s workshop. The painting, currently held in Florence’s Uffizi Gallery, shows an open, outdoor courtyard in Tuscany, where on the right the Virgin Mary reads from an open book and raises her hand in greeting to the kneeling angel Gabriel on the left, who holds a lily and tells Mary that she will bear the Christ child. While still bearing characteristics of an early work, elements of the painting’s composition were revolutionary for their time, including the use of a single central vanishing point. Leonardo likely based the table on which the Virgin’s book rests on a tomb Verrocchio had sculpted for the Medici family. The angel Gabriel’s wings were initially quite small; they were later enlarged by an artist other than Leonardo.

The Portrait of Ginevra de’ Benci (ca. late 1470s) is the only one of Leonardo’s works held in the United States; it is part of the collection of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. Ginevra de’ Benci was a notable Florentine noblewoman; the painting was likely commissioned to celebrate her engagement to Luigi di Bernardo Niccolini. At one point, the painting also showed Ginevra’s arms and lower chest; however, the lower portion was at some point cut off, leaving the modern, nearly square version. The contrast between the portrait and the later Mona Lisa is striking; instead of smiling, Ginevra looks out from the canvas with a dispassionate, flat expression, thought by many scholars to be a reference to her intelligence. Ginevra sits in front of a juniper bush, a reference to both her virtue and her name.

The Virgin of the Rocks (or Madonna of the Rocks) exists in two versions. The earlier of the two, painted in the 1480s likely entirely by Leonardo, is held in the Louvre; the second version, likely painted in the first decade of the 1500s, is held in London, and much debate exists on how much of it was completed by Leonardo’s assistants instead of the master. The painting gets its name from the rocky outcropping that comprises the background to a scene showing the Virgin Mary, the infants Jesus and John the Baptist, and an angel. While the major components and composition of the two paintings are the same, they differ in the specific colors used and in the angel’s pose and gaze. The work was originally commissioned as the central panel of an altarpiece in Milan’s Church of San Francesco Grande (demolished in the early 19th century).

The Great Horse for Ludovico Sforza (worked on during the 1480s–1490s), also known as Leonardo’s Horse or the Sforza Horse, was a planned but never completed massive statue. In 1481 Leonardo left Florence for Milan, where he was employed by Duke Ludovico Sforza; among the duke’s earliest commissions for Leonardo was for a 25-foot-tall statue of a horse intended as a monument to the duke’s father. Leonardo spent over a decade planning the work, including designing new processes to cast it, as a bronze work of that size had never before been attempted. In 1493 Leonardo completed a full-size clay model of the sculpture; however, an invasion by French king Charles VIII halted work on the actual statue, and Leonardo’s clay model was eventually destroyed. In the late 20th century, sculptor Nina Akamu created a design based on Leonardo’s work that was cast and finally unveiled in 1999.

Vitruvian Man (ca. 1490) is an ink-on-paper drawing showing two superimposed nude male figures—one standing straight up and touching the edges of a square, the other with splayed legs and raised arms touching the edge of a circle (with the figure’s navel at the circle’s center). The work’s name indicates Leonardo’s source of inspiration in creating it: Vitruvius was an ancient Roman architect whose writings about using human proportions in his designs led Leonardo to investigate those proportions. Leonardo’s written comments about said proportions appear above and below the drawing (such as that the fingertip-to-fingertip distance between one’s outstretched hands is equal to one’s height). Other details in the drawing were included to examine other proportions, such as one foot of each figure being drawn straight on, with the other being turned to the side.

Lady with an Ermine (ca. 1490) is a portrait of Cecilia Gallerani. Leonardo completed this painting during his time in Milan working for the Sforzas; Gallerani was one of Ludovico’s mistresses. The portrait shows Cecilia turning her head over her left shoulder while wearing a blue and red dress—colors also often used for the clothing of the Virgin Mary. In her arms, she cradles an ermine or stoat, a white weasel depicted larger than the actual real-life animal, and likely symbolizing Cecilia’s purity or chastity. At some point in the 1700s, the painting’s original background was covered with a flat black layer, and the name “Leonardo d’Awinci” and title “La Belle Ferronnière” added to the painting’s upper left corner—leading to much confusion with Leonardo’s actual other painting known as La Belle Ferronnière, thought to depict another of Ludovico’s mistresses.

The Last Supper (ca. 1498) is a mural painted on the refectory (or dining room) wall in Milan’s Santa Maria della Grazie, a Dominican convent. Because Leonardo painted the work using tempera directly onto a completed wall with a simple undercoat—as opposed to painting it as a fresco on wet plaster—the painting almost immediately began to decay; it has been restored several times throughout its life, to the point where very little, if any, of Leonardo’s original work remains. The composition of the painting has been the subject of much analysis: Christ’s announcement of his imminent betrayal has caused his apostles to fearfully confer in four groups of three, completely contrasting with Christ’s calm demeanor. Judas is portrayed with his head lower than anyone else’s, spilling over the salt, indicating he is the traitor. The Last Supper has inspired many conspiracy theories, including that the apostle John is actually meant to be Mary Magdalene, and that the position of everyone’s hands forms a musical composition.

The Mona Lisa (ca. 1503–1517) is not only Leonardo’s most recognizable painting, it is arguably the single most famous piece of art in the world. The Mona Lisa, also known as La Gioconda, is thought to depict Lisa, the wife of silk merchant Francesco del Giocondo. Leonardo never gave the painting to the Giocondo family; he carried it with him wherever he went, and continued sporadically working on it until just before his death. The work is renowned for its subject’s enigmatic smile, and seems to be looking directly at the viewer no matter where they are positioned. In 1911, Vincenzo Peruggia stole the painting from the Louvre—a task made more difficult by Leonardo having painted the work on a wood panel, rather than canvas—and hid it for two years, claiming he wished to return the painting to Italy. The Mona Lisa has inspired numerous works of both tribute and parody; Marcel Duchamp’s work L.H.O.O.Q. consists of a postcard of the Mona Lisa with facial hair added.

Saint John the Baptist (ca. 1515–1517) is likely Leonardo’s last completed work; he finished it just a few years before his death in 1519. The work shows John the Baptist tilting his head and smiling secretively at the viewer, clutching furs and a cross to his chest while curling his right arm to point upward. The model for John the Baptist was Salaì, Leonardo’s pupil and longtime companion. Many modern scholars have theorized that Leonardo and Salaì were lovers, and that the intimate nature of the painting represents their relationship. Leonardo’s portrait of John the Baptist is among the best examples of his signature use of sfumato (from the Italian word for “smoke”), a technique of blending colors to create a soft and smooth transition between them.

title: Jewish-american Authors
content:
Isaac Asimov (1920–1992) is considered one of the “Big Three” science fiction writers alongside Arthur C. Clarke and Robert Heinlein. His Robot series (1940–1995), which includes 37 short stories and six novels, opens with the smaller collection I, Robot, which centers on the robopsychologist Dr. Susan Calvin and her accounts of her life’s work to reporters. The collection introduces his Three Laws of Robotics: robots may not injure a human or allow them to be harmed; robots must obey a human’s orders; and robots must protect their existence. Asimov’s other well-known works include the Foundation series (1942–1993), in which the fall of the human Galactic Empire is mitigated by the work of the “psychohistorian” Hari Seldon, and such short stories as “The Last Question” (1956) and “Nightfall” (1941).

Saul Bellow (1915–2005) was born to Jewish parents in Montreal and wrote many works about Jewish life, though he often rejected the label of “Jewish writer.” His novel Herzog (1964) centers on Moses E. Herzog, a divorced Jewish professor who debates killing his second wife, Madeleine, and her new husband, Valentine, to gain custody of his daughter Junie. In the picaresque novel The Adventures of Augie March (1953), Bellow wrote about a Chicago-born “everyman” who marries Stella, whom he meets in Mexico after teaching an eagle how to catch iguanas with Thea Fenchel. In Humboldt’s Gift (1975), Bellow fictionalized himself as Charlie Citrine, the protégé of the writer Von Humboldt Fleisher, a stand-in for Bellow’s own mentor, the Jewish poet Delmore Schwartz. At age 85, Bellow wrote Ravelstein (2000), in which the dying title Jewish man Abe Ravelstein tells his life story to the narrator, who catches a tropical disease in the Caribbean before deciding to write Ravelstein’s memoir.

Michael Chabon (1963–) has explored his Jewish identity in novels such as The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay (2000). The title Jewish cousins, Joe Kavalier and Sammy Klayman, work at Empire Comics and create a character called the Escapist, who is voiced by the fictional actor Tracy Bacon, as well as Luna Moth, based on the bohemian Rosa Saks. In the novel, Kavalier comes to the US to live with Sammy after he escapes Nazi-occupied Prague by hiding in a coffin with a golem. The Yiddish Policemen’s Union (2007) focuses on Meyer Landsman, who works with Berko Shemets in a Jewish refugee settlement in Alaska to investigate threats to blow up the Dome of the Rock. He also wrote The Final Solution (2004), which centers on a beekeeper and retired detective (implied to be Sherlock Holmes) who searches for the parrot of Jewish refugee Linus Steinman.

Emma Lazarus (1849–1887) was a Jewish author and activist best known for her sonnet “The New Colossus” (1883), which was written to raise money for the Statue of Liberty’s pedestal and is now inscribed on a plaque in the pedestal itself. The poem opens “not like the brazen giant of Greek fame,” describing how Liberty cries out “give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free.” The poem, which was etched onto the statue’s pedestal, was inspired partly by her advocacy for Jewish refugees subject to persecution in Russia. Lazarus also wrote “In the Jewish Synagogue at Newport” (1871) as a rebuttal to Henry Wadsworth Longfellow’s “The Jewish Cemetery at Newport.”

Philip Roth (1933–2018) created the fictional Jewish character Nathan Zuckerman, often considered Roth’s alter ego, who appears in novels such as American Pastoral (1997). The novel focuses on Seymour “The Swede” Levov, who runs a glove factory in Newark and has a daughter who converts to Jainism after she bombs a post office to protest the Vietnam War. In Portnoy’s Complaint (1969), Roth wrote about the “nice Jewish boy” Alexander Portnoy, who monologues to his psychoanalyst Dr. Spielvogel about his parents Sophie and Jack, as well as his relationships with women he nicknames “The Monkey” (Mary Jane Reed) and “The Pumpkin.” Roth’s The Human Stain (2000), also narrated by Nathan Zuckerman, is about the Classics professor Coleman Silk, who was fired for using a racial slur, even though he is a Black man passing as white. Roth explored Jewish identity in short stories such as “The Conversion of the Jews” and “Defender of the Faith” in his short story collection Goodbye, Columbus (1959), which shares its title with a novella about Neil Klugman. Rising antisemitism forms the backdrop of Roth’s The Plot Against America (2004), an alternative history novel in which Charles Lindbergh defeats Franklin D. Roosevelt for president, leading to the increased persecution of Jews.

Isaac Bashevis Singer (1904–1991) was a Polish-born American short story author who wrote many works in Yiddish, drawing from the writings of earlier Yiddish authors such as Sholem Aleichem. Singer, who emigrated to the US in 1935 and worked for the Jewish Daily Forward, is perhaps best known for “Gimpel the Fool” (1953), in which the title breadmaker marries the unfaithful Elka and is told by the devil to urinate in the village’s bread to get revenge on his neighbors. “Gimpel the Fool,” like “The Spinoza of Market Street” and many more of Singer’s stories, is set in a fictionalized version of the Polish town of Frampol. His story “Yentl, the Yeshiva Boy,” about a young woman who disguises herself as a boy to study at a yeshiva, was adapted into a 1983 film starring Barbra Streisand. Singer also wrote the novel Satan in Goray (1933), about the title village amid the Khmelnitsky Uprising in Poland.

Bernard Malamud (1914–1986) was a Brooklyn-born author best known for his novel The Natural (1952). The novel centers on the baseball player Roy Hobbs, who tragically splits his prized bat “Wonderboy” in half. Hobbs plays for the New York Knights, which is managed by Pop Fisher. In the novel, Hobbs is shot by Harriet Byrd with a silver bullet, leading him to retire for 15 years, though during this time, he longs for Iris Lemon despite dating Memo Paris. Malamud more directly explored Judaism and antisemitism in his novel The Fixer (1966), an adaptation of the real-life story of Menahem Mendel Beilis, in which the handyman Yakov Bok is falsely accused of ritually killing a Christian boy during Passover and is tortured in tsarist Russia. Malamud is also known for “The Jewbird” (1963), a short story about a crow named Schwartz who endures antisemitism.

Chaim Potok (1929–2002) was an author and rabbi who sold over 3.4 million copies of his novel The Chosen (1967), which centers on the Hasidic boy Danny Saunders and the Orthodox boy Reuven Malter. The novel follows Danny’s decision to become a Freudian psychologist against the wishes of his rabbi father, while Reuven becomes a rabbi years after he is hit in the eye by a baseball. Potok’s other novels include My Name is Asher Lev (1972), whose title character distresses his traditionalist Hasidic father Aryeh by studying painting under Jacob Kahn and depicting his mother Rivkeh in his painting “Brooklyn Crucifixion,” and The Promise (1969), a sequel to The Chosen that centers Reuven and Danny amid post-World War II New York.

Arthur Miller (1915–2005) was born to a Polish-Jewish family in Harlem and achieved success with plays such as Death of a Salesman (1949) about the decline of Willy Loman, who crashes his car to provide insurance money for his wife Linda and his sons Biff and Happy after he is fired from his job and becomes obsessed with his own dreams. Miller’s play The Crucible (1953) is a depiction of the Salem witch trials written as an allegory for McCarthyism, in which John Proctor and Giles Corey are among those executed after Abigail Williams accuses many citizens of Salem of participating in witchcraft. Miller’s All My Sons (1947) is about Joe Keller, whose decision to sell faulty airplane pilots to the Air Force during World War II causes the imprisonment of his partner Steve Deever, the deaths of 21 pilots, and the suicide of his son Larry. After the Fall (1964), which is set entirely within the mind of its protagonist Quentin, was directly inspired by Miller’s divorce from Marilyn Monroe.

Neil Simon (1927–2018) was a Jewish-American playwright from New York City who grew up during the Great Depression, which framed some of his plays. Simon is best known for The Odd Couple (1965), which depicts the lazy Oscar Madison and his neat roommate Felix Ungar, who go on a disastrous double date with Cecily and Gwendolyn Pigeon. Simon won the 1991 Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Lost in Yonkers (1990), in which Arty and Jay Kurnitz live with their mentally challenged Aunt Bella and attempt to steal money from their grandmother, a store owner. Simon’s semi-autobiographical Eugene trilogy tells the story of Eugene Jerome, whose New York childhood, World War II basic training, and early comedy career are respectively chronicled in Brighton Beach Memoirs (1983), Biloxi Blues (1985), and Broadway Bound (1986).

title: Computer Components
content:
The CPU (central processing unit) is the heart of a computer. The CPU performs all of the binary operations responsible for a computer’s general functions and issues commands to the rest of the hardware. A modern CPU consists of multiple cores (processing units capable of running independently), which can be multithreaded to perform more than one set of calculations simultaneously; a high-end modern processor for a gaming PC may have 8 cores and 16 threads, whereas high-end workstations for video rendering and/or editing may have a CPU with 64 or even 96 cores. Modern CPU manufacturers include Intel and AMD (Advanced Micro Devices), whose chips are based on the 64-bit version of the x86 instruction set. In the early 2020s, Apple began designing its own line of Apple Silicon processors for its computers, based on the ARM instruction set (more common in smartphones and tablets).

The motherboard is a large printed circuit board connecting all of the main components of a computer. A typical motherboard will contain, at the very least, a socket for the CPU, multiple slots to insert RAM, slots in which to insert a graphics card and/or other expansion cards, connectors for storage drives, and an I/O panel that is available on the back of the case, which contains plugs for external peripherals, USB devices, networking ports, and more. A motherboard’s chipset manages the communication between a computer’s components, which occurs via the motherboard’s integrated circuits. In the 1990s and early 2000s, it was common for most desktops to have a separate sound card to manage sound output; since the early 2000s, most motherboards have had integrated sound, largely eliminating sound cards except in specialized applications.

RAM (random access memory) is a form of memory used to store data a computer expects to need within a short amount of time. Modern RAM comes in sticks called DIMMs (dual inline memory modules). RAM generally stores information based on whether capacitors are charged or uncharged. RAM is volatile memory, meaning that any information stored in it is lost when the computer is shut down or powered off (unlike information stored on a hard drive). Nearly all RAM in modern desktop computers is SDRAM (synchronous dynamic RAM), meaning that an external clock cycle controls the speed at which information is written to and read from the RAM, which must be refreshed at certain intervals. Most modern desktop RAM also uses the DDR (double data rate) standard, meaning that data can be read or written twice within a single clock cycle. The speed of RAM is also partially measured by its CAS (column address strobe) latency, the number of clock cycles between when data is requested and received.

Hard drives (HDDs) are non-volatile devices for storing data, meaning that the data is not lost when the computer is turned off. By and large, hard drives still operate on the same basic principles as when they were first developed in the 1950s: data is magnetically written onto a number of fast-spinning metal plates or disks. Hard drives remain the cheapest used storage solution per unit of data (among solutions used commonly for general purposes). Most modern desktop computers will include at least one hard drive for bulk data storage, though it will likely not be the system’s primary drive. Nearly all modern desktop hard drives are of the 3.5″ size, spin at 5400 or 7200 RPM, and connect to the motherboard via a SATA cable.

Solid state drives (SSDs) are non-volatile devices that store data on flash memory, which utilizes transistors. Because the drive essentially uses electricity, rather than physically spinning media, to store information, SSD read/write speeds are much faster than those of hard drives, but they are also more expensive: a 2-terabyte SSD may cost around $200, while the same amount of money may purchase an 8-terabyte hard drive. SSDs first began to be widely adopted in the consumer market in the early 2010s. There are currently two main types of SSDs: 2.5″ drives, which connect to the motherboard with a SATA cable (like hard drives); and M.2 NVME drives, which are the size of a stick of gum, connect directly to a slot on the motherboard, and represent the fastest easily available non-volatile consumer storage solution today. Most modern computers will include at least one SSD as the main drive on which the operating system is installed, allowing for much faster boot times than a hard drive.

A graphics card, containing a GPU, generates the visual images that are output to a monitor. Nearly all computers designed for gaming will use a discrete graphics card; systems for general business purposes and most non-gaming laptops instead use integrated graphics, meaning the CPU also acts as the GPU. The two main manufacturers of discrete consumer graphics cards are Nvidia (with its GeForce cards) and AMD (with its Radeon cards); beginning in 2022, Intel also began manufacturing discrete GPUs with its Arc line of products. A modern discrete graphics card will include its own processing unit (the actual graphics processing unit, or GPU), as well as several gigabytes of dedicated RAM. Nvidia’s development of CUDA technology in the 2000s allowed for GPU processing power to be used by other applications. Over the past decade, this has led to a spike in GPU prices and numerous shortages of available products, as GPUs have become critical to both cryptocurrency mining and generative AI.

The power supply unit (PSU) supplies power to all other components of a computer by converting the alternating current from an outlet into direct current. Power supplies are rated by both how many watts of power they are able to provide a system, and their 80 Plus rating—a measure of the efficiency of their power delivery; for example, an 850 Gold PSU can deliver up to 850 watts of power at between 87 and 90 percent efficiency under load. Modern power supplies for enthusiast desktops are often modular, meaning that the user only needs to connect cables for the components that they need or have—reducing the amount of cable clutter within a case. While power supplies deliver different voltages for different components, by far the most important is the 12-volt rail, as the most power-hungry of a system’s components—the CPU and GPU—use it.

PCI Express (Peripheral Component Interface Express or PCIe) is a connection standard used for computer hardware. First developed in 2003, PCIe began life as a new standard for connecting graphics cards that replaced the older, slower AGP (Acceleratic Graphics Port) standard. However, its speed and versatility meant that soon it became the standard for all sorts of components, including sound cards and other expansion cards; modern M.2 NVME drives also utilize PCIe. PCIe operates on a number of lanes for transmitting data, from one to 16; most modern GPU slots utilize a 16-lane connection. Because of PCIe’s ubiquity, it is common for both the CPU and motherboard chipset to include separate PCIe controllers that are linked to different inputs; it is also, consequently, possible to install so many PCIe devices on one controller that it limits the available lanes and reduces performance.

The BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) or UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) is the first piece of software that runs upon powering on a computer. Although the terms “BIOS” and “UEFI” technically refer to different things (BIOS being an older IBM standard that has been superseded by UEFI), the terms are still commonly used interchangeably. The BIOS performs a computer’s POST (power-on self test), ensuring all hardware components are functioning, and manages the boot order, determining which drive/operating system will be given priority to run. Updating a computer’s BIOS (known as flashing the BIOS) was once a process fraught with danger, as if the computer was turned off or otherwise lost power, the BIOS could be corrupted and render the system completely unusable; most modern motherboards, however, include a BIOS flashback feature that allows the BIOS to be updated or reloaded in any situation, even if the system doesn’t have a CPU.

Cooling a desktop computer is a complicated but important task. Modern CPUs and GPUs generate an enormous amount of heat (running at 70°C to 80°C under load with adequate cooling) that must be dissipated for the system to continue to run. There are two main types of modern CPU coolers. An air cooler typically features a very large heatsink (a mass of thermally conductive metal attached directly to the CPU), with fans blowing over it constantly to exhaust the heat it draws away from the CPU. A liquid cooler passes a coolant fluid over a cold plate in contact with the CPU to draw the heat into the liquid, then pumps the liquid through a radiator for heat exchange. A system will also include multiple case fans to maximize the flow of cool air into, and warm air out of, the case. Failing to adequately cool a system can result in thermal throttling, when a component intentionally lowers its performance level to avoid reaching and/or running at dangerous temperatures.

title: Techniques In Biotechnology
content:
PCR (polymerase chain reaction) is a technique used to amplify small segments of DNA. It allows scientists to generate millions of copies of a specific DNA sequence from a small initial sample. Developed by Kary Mullis in 1983, PCR involves repeated cycles of heating and cooling, performed using an instrument called a thermal cycler (or thermocycler). PCR is divided into three steps. First, denaturation heats a double-stranded DNA template, separating the two strands. Second, annealing lowers the temperature, allowing short single-stranded DNA strands called primers to bind to the template. Finally, extension allows DNA polymerase to extend the attached primers along the template. Taq polymerase, a DNA polymerase isolated from the bacteria Thermus aquaticus, is commonly used in PCR due to its heat stability. Variants of PCR include real-time PCR (or qPCR), which allows the amount of amplified product to be measured in real time, as well as reverse transcription PCR (or RT-PCR), which allows for quantification of RNA by converting RNA into complementary DNA prior to amplification.

Gel electrophoresis is used to separate nucleic acids or proteins based on their size and charge. It provides information on the size and quantity of DNA or protein fragments, enabling scientists to confirm the presence of specific genetic sequences or proteins. During gel electrophoresis, DNA, RNA, or protein samples are loaded into a gel matrix, such as agarose or polyacrylamide, and an electric current is applied. Molecules migrate through the gel, with smaller fragments moving faster than larger ones. During separation, buffers such as TAE (Tris-Acetate-EDTA) and TBE (Tris-Borate-EDTA) maintain pH, provide ions for conduction, and preserve sample stability. After separation, bands are visualized using staining methods such as ethidium bromide for nucleic acids or Coomassie brilliant blue for proteins. If the experiment is run alongside a set of molecules with known sizes called a ladder, the resulting bands may be compared against the ladder to determine the size of the fragments. SDS-PAGE is a variant of gel electrophoresis in which proteins are denatured using SDS (sodium dodecyl sulfate), conferring a uniform negative charge to all fragments and allowing for separation by size alone.

DNA sequencing is the process of determining the exact order of nucleotides within a DNA molecule. The first breakthrough in the field, Sanger sequencing, was developed by Frederick Sanger in 1977 and utilizes dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs), which terminate DNA strand elongation when incorporated. A DNA sample is then subjected to denaturation, annealing, and elongation, with ddNTPs creating a set of fragments of varying lengths, each ending with a labeled ddNTP. In contrast, shotgun sequencing randomly fragments DNA strands, sequences those fragments into reads, then reassembles overlapping reads to recover the full sequence. Modern advancements in DNA sequencing include next-generation sequencing (or NGS) technologies, which allow for rapid, high-throughput sequencing of entire genomes. Industry leaders in next-generation sequencing include the US-based Illumina, who utilizes dye sequencing to facilitate massive parallel sequencing, as well as the UK-based Oxford Nanopore Technologies, whose nanopore sequencing method passes DNA samples through pores and measures changes in electric current across the pore.

Northern blotting is a technique used to detect and study specific RNA molecules within a sample. Developed by James Alwine, David Kemp, and George Stark in 1977, it allows scientists to determine the size, abundance, and expression patterns of RNA. The process begins with the extraction of RNA from a biological sample, followed by its separation by size through gel electrophoresis. The separated RNA fragments are then blotted onto a nylon or nitrocellulose membrane. To detect specific RNA sequences, the membrane is hybridized with a labeled probe that is complementary to the target RNA. After hybridization, the membrane is washed to remove unbound probes, and the signal is detected using autoradiography or a similar detection method. Northern blotting is widely used in gene expression studies, allowing researchers to compare RNA levels across different tissues or developmental stages. It is particularly valuable in identifying and quantifying mRNA levels, providing insights into gene regulation.

Western blotting is a powerful analytical technique used to detect specific proteins in a complex mixture. Developed by W. Neal Burnette in 1981, this method allows scientists to determine the presence, size, and abundance of proteins. The process begins with the extraction of proteins from a sample, followed by their separation based on size using SDS-PAGE. The separated proteins are then blotted onto a membrane, typically made of nitrocellulose or PVDF (polyvinylidene fluoride). To detect the target protein, the membrane is incubated with a primary antibody specific to the protein of interest. After washing away unbound primary antibodies, the membrane is incubated with a secondary antibody that recognizes the primary antibody and is conjugated to a detection enzyme or fluorescent tag. The presence of the target protein is then visualized using chemiluminescence, fluorescence, or colorimetric detection methods. Western blotting is widely used in molecular biology, biochemistry, and medical diagnostics to study protein expression, post-translational modifications, and protein-protein interactions.

Southern blotting is a method used to detect specific DNA sequences within a complex DNA sample. Developed by Edwin Southern in 1975, this technique enables researchers to identify, isolate, and study particular DNA fragments. The process begins with the extraction and restriction enzyme digestion of DNA. The resulting fragments are then separated by size using gel electrophoresis. The separated DNA is transferred onto a nylon or nitrocellulose membrane through capillary action, where the DNA fragments retain their relative positions. To detect specific sequences, the blotted membrane is hybridized with a labeled DNA probe complementary to the target sequence. After hybridization, the membrane is washed to remove unbound probes, and the signal is detected using autoradiography or a similar detection method. Southern blotting is commonly used in gene mapping, cloning verification, and genetic screening, providing valuable information about gene structure and organization as well as the presence of specific genetic elements.

ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) is a widely used technique for detecting and quantifying specific proteins, antibodies, antigens, and hormones in a sample. Developed in the 1970s, ELISA is based on the principle of antigen-antibody interaction. There are several types of ELISA, including direct, indirect, sandwich, and competitive, the most popular of which is sandwich ELISA. In a typical sandwich ELISA, the process begins by coating a microplate with a capture antibody specific to the target antigen. The sample is added, and any antigen present binds to the capture antibody. A detection antibody, which is also specific to the antigen and conjugated to an enzyme, is then added. After washing away unbound substances, a substrate for the enzyme is added, producing a measurable color change, fluorescence, or luminescence. The intensity of the signal correlates with the amount of target antigen in the sample. ELISA is highly sensitive and specific, making it a standard tool in clinical diagnostics, vaccine development, and research to measure biomarkers and disease-related molecules.

CRISPR/Cas9 is a revolutionary genome-editing technology derived from a bacterial immune system. It allows precise modification of DNA within living organisms. Discovered in the early 2010s by Jennifer Doudna and Emmanuelle Charpentier, the duo shared the 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for their discovery. The system consists of two key components: the Cas9 enzyme and a guide RNA (gRNA). The gRNA is designed to match the target DNA sequence, guiding Cas9 to the specific location in the genome. Once there, Cas9 creates a double-strand break in the DNA. The cell’s natural repair mechanisms then kick in, either joining the ends back together through NHEJ (non-homologous end joining), which can introduce mutations, or through HDR (homology-directed repair), which uses a provided DNA template to insert new sequences. This precise targeting allows for gene knockout, insertion, or correction. In November 2018, CRISPR/Cas9 technology was controversially used by Chinese researcher He Jiankui to target the CCR5 gene in a pair of twins in an attempt to confer HIV resistance to them.

Flow cytometry is a technique used to analyze the physical and chemical characteristics of cells or particles as they pass in a stream through a laser. Developed in the 1960s, this method labels cells with fluorescent markers that bind to specific cell components, such as proteins or nucleic acids. Techniques such as hydrodynamic focusing and acoustic focusing ensure cells remain in single file as they pass through the beam. As cells move through the laser, light emitted by fluorescent markers—along with forward-scattered light (FSC light) and side-scattered light (SSC light)—are captured by detectors. The resulting data is analyzed using techniques such as compensation and gating to determine cell size, granularity, and the presence of specific markers. Flow cytometry is often combined with fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) in the Flow-FISH technique, which is used to quantify the copy number of repetitive elements like telomeres. It is also widely used for fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS), as well as for immunophenotyping, cell counting, and biomarker detection.

Molecular cloning is a technique used to create multiple copies of a specific DNA segment. It involves the insertion of a DNA fragment of interest into a vector, a DNA molecule capable of replication in a host organism, usually a plasmid. The process begins with the isolation of the DNA fragment to be cloned. The isolated DNA is then fragmented using restriction enzymes, while the selected vector is digested using the same restriction enzyme. The DNA fragments and vectors are mixed in the presence of DNA ligase. The resulting recombinant vector is introduced into a host cell, often a bacterium, through a process called transformation. As the host cell replicates, it also replicates the recombinant vector, producing multiple copies of the DNA fragment. Often, an antibacterial resistance gene is incorporated into the vector, allowing only cells that have taken up the vector to survive. The cloned DNA can then be isolated and used for various applications, such as gene expression studies, genetic engineering, and functional analysis.

title: Organic Reactions
content:
Redox reactions change the oxidation state of a compound by reducing or oxidizing it. A compound that is oxidized loses electrons, while a compound that is reduced gains electrons. In the context of organic molecules, an oxidation reaction tends to reduce the number of carbon–hydrogen bonds and increase the number of bonds between carbon and oxygen or other atoms, such as nitrogen, halogens, etc. Reduction reactions do the opposite, increasing carbon–hydrogen bonds and decreasing carbon–oxygen and carbon–other atom bonds. For example, the conversion of an alkene to an alkane increases the number of carbon–hydrogen bonds and is thus a reduction. Redox reactions can convert between useful functional groups such as alcohols, carbonyls, and carboxylic acid derivatives. Alcohols can be oxidized to carbonyls, which can be oxidized to carboxylic acid derivatives; the reverse order can occur through reduction reactions. Oxidation is frequently performed with chromium-based oxidants such as PCC or Jones’ reagent. Reductions are frequently performed with hydride reducing agents like sodium borohydride (Na B H4) or lithium aluminum hydride (Li Al H4).

Addition reactions are a type of reaction in which two molecules combine to produce a larger molecule with no loss of atoms from either of the reactants. Organic addition reactions can be categorized as electrophilic or nucleophilic depending on whether the molecule being added has a group that accepts electron pairs (and thus “loves electrons” and is an electrophile) or if the molecule being added has a group that donates electron pairs to positively-charged nuclei (and thus “loves nuclei” and is a nucleophile). For example, in the electrophilic addition reaction between an alkene and molecular bromine (Br2), bromine acts as an electrophile, accepting electrons from the alkene, the nucleophile. Addition reactions to alkenes may be regioselective, meaning the added substituent may selectively prefer to bond to one of the two alkene carbon atoms over the other carbon atom; such regioselectivity can in many cases be described by Markovnikov’s rule.

Substitution reactions are a type of reaction in which one group on a larger molecule is replaced with a different group. The incoming group is usually a nucleophile, and the group that is replaced is called a leaving group. There are two basic types of substitution reactions, denoted SN2 (which stands for “bimolecular nucleophilic substitution”) and SN1 (which stands for “unimolecular nucleophilic substitution”). An SN2 reaction is called “bimolecular” and has a “2” in its abbreviation because its rate-determining step depends on two molecules, with the nucleophile attacking the leaving group via a backside attack. An SN1 reaction is called “unimolecular” and has a “1” in its abbreviation since its rate-determining step depends on one molecule: first, the leaving group leaves by itself spontaneously, forming an unstable carbocation intermediate, then the nucleophile comes in afterward. The Williamson ether synthesis is a typical substitution reaction; in it, an alcohol replaces the halogen in an alkyl halide via an SN2 mechanism, making an ether.

Elimination reactions are the opposite of an addition reaction: instead of two molecules coming together to form one molecule, two groups (or, more commonly, one group and a hydrogen atom) are removed from a molecule to form two molecules. The original molecule then usually is stabilized by the creation of a pi bond. This is most commonly observed to create alkenes by eliminating across a carbon–carbon single bond. Just like substitution reactions, basic elimination reactions come in E2 (bimolecular elimination) and E1 (unimolecular elimination) types. Like in SN2 reactions, in E2 reactions the reaction occurs in a single rate-determining step involving both molecules as the leaving group and the adjacent hydrogen leave at the same time. E2 reactions require an anti-periplanar arrangement of the leaving group and the exiting hydrogen to proceed. Like SN1 reactions, in E1 reactions the rate-determining step involves one molecule as the leaving group leaves spontaneously to form an unstable carbocation, then afterwards the hydrogen is removed to form the pi bond. Similar to Markovnikov’s rule for addition reactions, the regioselectivity of some elimination reactions obeys Zaitsev’s rule, in which the leaving hydrogen is removed from the carbon attached to the fewest hydrogens, thus creating the most substituted alkene.

Condensation reactions are a type of reaction in which two molecules combine to form a single molecule, with the removal of a small molecule in the process (usually water, hence the name). A classic example of a condensation reaction is the Fischer esterification, in which a carboxylic acid reacts with an alcohol to produce an ester. The Fischer esterification requires an acid catalyst to protonate the carbonyl oxygen in the carboxylic acid. Another condensation reaction is the aldol condensation, in which two carbonyl-containing compounds combine to form an alpha–beta unsaturated ketone, which means a ketone that is directly connected to an alkene. The aldol condensation can be catalyzed by either an acid or a base, with the acid generating an intermediate enol, or the base generating an intermediate enolate.

Hydrogenation is a special type of reduction reaction in which a molecule of hydrogen (H2) is added to an organic molecule. It is most typically used to convert alkenes (double bonds) to alkanes (single bonds). This is commonly used in the processing of fats, in which unsaturated fatty acids—which have double and triple bonds—are hydrogenated until they are saturated with hydrogen atoms, thus becoming saturated fats. Incomplete hydrogenation can lead to the production of trans alkenes, thus creating trans fats. William Knowles and Ryoji Noyori won the 2001 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for independently developing stereoselective hydrogenation reactions. This essentially means that the reaction preferentially adds the hydrogens to a particular side of a molecule, forming a chiral molecule, a molecule that cannot be superimposed on its mirror image. (Think about your left hand and right hand: if you move one of them over the other without rotating, the hands don’t overlap cleanly because your thumbs are on opposite sides. Your hands are chiral! These stereoselective reactions are capable of producing either only the left-handed molecule, or only the right-handed molecule.) Stereoselective hydrogenation can be used to make the drug L-DOPA, which is used to treat Parkinson’s disease.

The Diels–Alder reaction is a cycloaddition reaction that combines a diene and a dienophile to form a cyclic compound, typically a six-carbon cyclohexene ring. The dienophile is typically an alkene, but can also be another functional group with an appropriate pi bond (such as an alkyne). Due to the cyclic transition state of the Diels–Alder reaction, it belongs to the pericyclic class of reactions. The stereochemistry of a Diels–Alder reaction kinetically has a preference for the endo product, because that configuration maximizes the orbital overlap between the two reactants. Frontier molecular orbital theory can be used to describe the electron flow in a Diels–Alder reaction: electrons flow from the HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) of the diene to the LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) of the dienophile. This means that the Diels–Alder reaction can be accelerated by adding electron-donating groups (EDGs) to the diene and electron-withdrawing groups (EWGs) to the dienophile.

The Wittig reaction converts carbonyls into alkenes. This is typically accomplished with a Wittig reagent, which is a phosphonium ylide, a type of molecule with a positively-charged phosphorus atom directly bonded to a negatively-charged carbon atom. The ylide can be made by taking an alkylated phosphonium salt and treating it with a strong organolithium base (like n-butyllithium). This ylide then reacts with the carbonyl to form a four-membered ring called an oxaphosphetane, which decomposes to give the product alkene, plus triphenylphosphine oxide as a side product. Wittig reactions typically produce (Z) alkenes, meaning the two largest substituents are on the same side of the double bond. The Horner–Wadsworth–Emmons reaction is a modification of the Wittig reaction that employs “stabilized” ylides to instead produce (E) alkenes, in which the two largest substituents are on opposite sides of the double bond.

Electrophilic aromatic substitution (EAS) reactions are substitution reactions that can replace groups on an aromatic ring like benzene. These use a different mechanism than SN2 or SN1, as aromatic carbons are difficult to nucleophilically attack. While there are six positions on a benzene ring to add a new substituent, you often only want to add the group to one position, which can be accomplished with the aid of directing groups. For example, the hydroxyl group in the molecule phenol is an ortho/para director, meaning the new group will be added either next to the hydroxyl (ortho), or on the opposite side of the ring to the hydroxyl (para). Nitro groups are meta-directors, which influence the addition of the new substituent two carbon atoms away from the nitro group (meta). The Friedel–Crafts reactions are a prominent example of an electrophilic aromatic substitution, in which an alkyl or acyl group is added to an aromatic ring. Friedel–Crafts reactions typically use a Lewis acid, such as aluminum trichloride, as a catalyst.

Coupling reactions combine two molecules or fragments into one larger product, usually with the aid of organometallic reagents to form new carbon–carbon bonds (which are difficult to make, but desirable). The 2010 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Akira Suzuki, Richard Heck, and Ei-ichi Negishi for developing coupling reactions named for them (the Suzuki coupling, the Negishi coupling, and the Heck reaction). All coupling reactions have a mechanism that contains a catalytic cycle, allowing for a very small amount of catalyst (usually a palladium complex) to propagate the reaction. Suzuki reactions usually couple a boronic ester to a vinyl or aryl halide, while Heck reactions couple an alkene to a vinyl or aryl halide.

title: Ideas From Calculus
content:
A limit is a value that a function approaches as the input approaches another value, even if the function is not equal to that output value (or even defined there). For example, the limit of 1/x as x gets infinity large (“approaches infinity”) is 0, even though the function never actually reaches 0. The definition of a limit is formalized in a way traditionally written with the Greek letters epsilon and delta, a technique developed by Augustin-Louis Cauchy.

Continuity is informally defined as the ability of a function’s graph to be drawn without lifting the pen. Properly, a function is continuous at a given point if the function has a limit at that point and is equal to its limit there. It is also common to speak of “continuous functions,” which are functions that are continuous at every point. Polynomials are continuous, as are exponential and logarithmic functions, sine, and cosine. However, the other four trigonometric functions (cosecant, secant, tangent, and cotangent) are not continuous at some points (the ones at which their graphs have asymptotes), and rational functions generally have some points of discontinuity.

The derivative is an operation that takes a function and results in another function that gives the original function’s rate of change. Taking a derivative is called differentiation and is carried out with respect to the input variable that is changing. The derivative is calculated as the limit of a tangent line between two points on the function’s graph as the two points get arbitrarily close together. At any given point, the derivative’s value is equal to the slope of the tangent line to the function’s graph at that point. The derivative of a function f(x) is notated as f′(x) (Lagrange’s notation, pronounced “f prime of x”) or df/dx (Leibniz notation, pronounced “d f d x). Differentiation can be repeated, e.g,. differentiating a function twice gives its second derivative (f′′(x) or d²f/dx²).

A function is called differentiable if its derivative can be evaluated. Like for continuity, this can be stated about a specific point or the whole function. The absolute value function is an example of a function that is differentiable in some places but not others: it is differentiable everywhere except at an input of 0, where its graph has a sharp corner. Differentiability is a stronger property than continuity: a function can only be differentiable if it is continuous, but it could be only continuous and not differentiable (the absolute value function being an example of that). If a function’s derivative can be taken infinitely many times, it is called smooth.

Definite integration is an operation that can be interpreted as giving the area under a curve, or more precisely, the signed area between the curve and the x-axis (signed area meaning that area below the axis counts as negative). An integral is denoted by a “long S” symbol, ∫. Definite integration is performed between two endpoints (e.g., the integral between 0 and 5), and those endpoints are written above and below, or next to, the integral symbol.

Riemann sums are a way to formalize the definition of an integral. A Riemann sum approximates the area under a curve by partitioning the area into narrow rectangles that extend between the x-axis and the function’s graph, finding the areas of the rectangles, and adding those up. For well-behaved functions, the limit can be taken as the rectangles get infinitely thin, giving the definite integral.

The fundamental theorem of calculus roughly states that integration and differentiation are opposite operations. This means that most basic rules for integration can be found by reversing the basic rules for differentiation given above. The formal statement of the theorem is usually given in two parts. The first part states that integrating a function gives an antiderivative of the function (i.e., a function whose derivative is the original function). The second part states that the definite integral of f(x) from a to b can be calculated as F(b) − F(a), where F is an antiderivative of f.

The chain rule is used to find the derivative of the composition of two functions, such as sin(x²). It states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f′(g(x)) · g′(x). In Leibniz notation, it is written as df/dx = df/dg dg/dx and thus resembles canceling two fractions. Integrating both sides of this result gives a corresponding rule for integration by substitution.

The product rule is used to find the derivative of the product of two functions, such as x sin x. It states that the derivative of f(x) g(x) is f′(x) g(x) + f(x) g′(x). Integrating both sides of this result gives a corresponding rule for integrating the product of two functions, called integration by parts. It can be combined with the chain rule to find the quotient rule (the way to differentiate a function written as one function divided by another).

Taylor series is a way of approximating a differentiable function using an infinite sum of monomials (which can be truncated to get a polynomial). Coefficients of Taylor series are found using nth derivatives and the factorial function. Taylor series can be based around any point of a function, and when the chosen point is x = 0, it is called a Maclaurin series. Taylor’s theorem gives a bound on the error resulting from truncating the Taylor series to a finite number of terms; the error can be expressed as a remainder term in the Lagrange form, Cauchy form, or integral form.

Differential equations are equations that relate a function to its derivatives, or even multiple derivatives (e.g., a function to its first and second derivatives). They are widely used throughout the sciences to model behavior like radioactive decay, population growth, predator-prey relations, waves, fluid flow, and more.

title: Indigenous Peoples
content:
Aboriginal Australians comprise various indigenous peoples who lived in Australia before European settlers arrived. Traditionally, Aboriginal peoples believed that Australia was created during a mythical period called the Dreamtime, during which beings like the Rainbow Serpent ruled. When the British arrived in Australia, they persecuted Aboriginal people and seized their land in the Frontier Wars. In the 1900s, many Aboriginal children were taken from their families, becoming known as the Stolen Generations. While European mistreatment of Aboriginal people is recognized on National Sorry Day, they still face discrimination, including higher rates of poverty and incarceration. Aboriginal people are distinct from the Torres Strait Islanders, who live north of mainland Australia.

The Ainu people are indigenous to Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan’s home islands. They also live in other northern Pacific areas like Sakhalin and the Kuril Islands. For centuries, the Ainu traded with ethnically Japanese people on Honshu, but were conquered around 1800 by the Tokugawa Shogunate. Ainu people are generally taller than ethnically Japanese people and are set apart by their longer beards and distinctive facial tattoos, particularly among women. Traditional Ainu communities both hunted and worshiped bears, which are native to Hokkaido.

The Basque people are indigenous to northern Spain and southwestern France. Most live in the Basque Country (or Euskadi), a wealthy region within Spain that includes cities like Bilbao and San Sebastian. Many speak Basque, a language isolate that emerged earlier than even Proto-Indo European. The Basques have a long history of independence from larger powers, having defeated Charlemagne at the Battle of Roncevaux Pass and formed the Kingdom of Navarre. In the 20th century, some Basques fought to become independent from Spain by supporting the terrorist group ETA.

The Inuit peoples are indigenous to the Arctic portions of North America, particularly the Canadian territory of Nunavut. They are distinct from the First Nations and have a long history of contact with Europeans dating to the Viking settlement of Greenland. Inuit peoples traditionally lived through whaling and other forms of hunting. To survive in the harsh climate, they developed kayaks and parkas, while some Inuit people would seek shelter in igloos. The first full-length documentary, Nanook of the North, depicted a somewhat-accurate version of Inuit life in 1922. In the past, Inuit were known in English as “Eskimos”; that term is now considered offensive.

The Kurds are indigenous to Kurdistan, a mountainous region stretching between Turkey, Iraq, and Iran. For thousands of years, Kurds played a major role in Persian and Islamic civilization. During the Crusades, the Kurdish leader Saladin founded the Ayyubid Dynasty that ruled Egypt, Syria, and Arabia. After being denied their own country in the wake of the Ottoman Empire, many Kurdish people demanded independence. The Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or PKK, has fought a long conflict against the government of Turkey. In Iraq, Saddam Hussein committed genocide against the Kurds, who now control an autonomous Iraqi region defended by the Peshmerga military.

The Maori people are indigenous to New Zealand, which is known as Aotearoa in their language. The Maori are a Polynesian group who arrived as the first human settlers of New Zealand in the 1300s. In 1840 they signed the Treaty of Waitangi, which promised peaceful coexistence with new settlers from Britain. Despite later repression, Maori customs and culture remain a major part of life in New Zealand, exemplified by the traditional Maori haka dance performed by the country’s national rugby team. Many Maori practice ta moko, the art of tattooing.

The Maya people are indigenous to southern Mexico and Central America. They formed the ancient Mayan Civilization, which developed in the Yucatan peninsula. The Maya built cities like Tikal and Palenque, as well as the great pyramid of Chichen Itza, before declining in the ninth century. Today, most Mayan people live in Guatemala, where thousands were killed during a U.S.-backed genocide in the 1980s. For advocating on behalf of Mayan people, Rigoberta Menchú won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1992.

The Quechua people are a collection of indigenous people in western South America, connected by speaking Quechua languages. They predominantly live around the Andes Mountains in Peru. Quechua people formed the Inca civilization, which emerged in the 1400s. The Inca built a system of roads that stretched thousands of miles and constructed cities like Machu Picchu. They were conquered by Spanish forces under Francisco Pizzaro in the early sixteenth century. Quechua people were the first to domesticate potatoes and inspired the English word “jerky.”

The Rapa Nui people are indigenous to Easter Island in the southern Pacific Ocean. The Rapa Nui are Polynesian and first settled on the island around 1200. They constructed massive stone figures known as Moai, which feature large elongated heads. The introduction of rats to Easter Island led to deforestation in the 18th century and a large decline in the Rapa Nui population. Today, about 10,000 Rapa Nui people live as citizens of Chile on Easter Island, with most residing in the town of Hanga Roa.

The Sami people are indigenous to northern Scandinavia. Because the harsh Arctic climate makes farming difficult, Sami people traditionally lived by herding reindeer and other animals. Following the Black Death, many Sami people migrated south to repopulate agricultural communities, but they faced persistent discrimination. However, many Sami retain traditional practices like joik, a style of folk singing which inspired the opening number of Disney’s Frozen. The Sami were traditionally known in English as “Lapps” or “Laplanders,” but those terms are now considered offensive.

title: Geometric Curves
content:
The circle is a curve consisting of the points that are an equal distance (called the radius) from a particular point (called the center). The irrational constant pi can be defined as the ratio of the circle’s circumference (the circle-specific term for perimeter) to its diameter (equal to twice the radius); the circle’s area is pi times the radius squared. A sector is the wedge-like shape bounded by two radii and an arc of the circumference; a chord is a straight line segment joining two points on the circumference. Cyclic shapes are shapes for which it is possible to draw a circle that goes through all the shape’s vertices; all triangles and all rectangles (including squares) are cyclic, but many quadrilaterals are not. The Cartesian equation (x−h)2 + (y−k)2 = r2 gives a circle of radius r centered at (h, k).

The circle is the simplest of the conic sections, which are the class of curves formed by the intersection of a plane with a double cone (two cones with the same axis, joined at the apex). Another definition of conic sections is that, for any point P on the curve, the distance from P to a point called the focus is equal to a constant multiple of the distance from P to a line called the directrix; the constant multiple is the eccentricity, a dimensionless number that describes how “squashed” the curve is or how far away it is from being a circle. For example, for a circle, the focus is the center, the directrix is a “line at infinity,” and the eccentricity is therefore zero. The next three entries are the other three conic sections, other than degenerate conic sections (a single point and various configurations of lines, are considered degenerate conics, meaning they can arise from mathematical definitions of conic sections but are not meaningful curves).

Ellipses are conic sections that resemble ovals. Their eccentricity is less than 1, and some definitions treat a circle as a special case of the ellipse. On an ellipse, the sum of the distances to two foci is constant. Their major axis and minor axis are the line segments within the ellipse that lie on their axes of symmetry, with the former being longer than the latter. In Cartesian coordinates, an ellipse has an equation of the form (x−h)2 + (y−k)2 = 1, where (h, k) is the center and a and b are the semimajor and semiminor axes (half the length of the major and minor axes, in either order depending on which is greater). The orbits of planets trace out ellipses, per Kepler’s first law.

Parabolas are conic sections that are open, meaning the curve does not “come back to meet itself.” They all have the same eccentricity, 1, meaning all parabolas are similar to one another and, for any point on the parabola, the distance to the directrix equals the distance to the single focus. The standard equation for an upward-opening parabola is x2 = 4 a y, with the focus being at (0, a). In Cartesian coordinates, the graph of any quadratic single-variable polynomial is a parabola. In a constant gravitational field, the path of a projectile is an arc of a parabola.

Hyperbolas are conic sections with eccentricity greater than 1. On a hyperbola, the difference of the distances to two foci is constant. Hyperbolas have two branches, each of which tends towards a pair of asymptotes. In Cartesian coordinates, an ellipse has an equation of the form (x−h)2 − (y−k)2 = 1, where (h, k) is the center.

The cycloid is the curve traced out by a point on the circumference of a circle as it rolls once along a straight line without slipping. Portions of a cycloid provide the solution to the brachistochrone problem, which is to identify the curve between two points so that a particle sliding frictionlessly down the curve will slide as fast as possible. The cycloid also provides the solution for the tautochrone problem, which seeks a curve for which the time taken for a particle to descend the curve does not depend on the initial position.

The catenary is the shape of a uniformly heavy chain (catena in Latin) suspended from two points at the same height in a constant gravitational field. The equations (in Cartesian coordinates) for catenaries use the hyperbolic cosine function. All catenaries are similar to each other. Though catenaries look similar to parabolas, y scales exponentially with x rather than quadratically as for the parabola.

The Witch of Agnesi is a bell-shaped curve given by the graph of y = 1 / (1 + x2). When rescaled, it becomes the probability density function for the Cauchy or Lorentzian distribution, which is well-defined but nevertheless has no well-defined mean. It was popularized by the mathematician Maria Agnesi, the first woman to receive a position as a math professor (though she apparently did not take it up). Its unusual name comes from a translator misreading its Italian name “versiera” as “avversiera,” meaning “witch.”

There are several types of spirals, all of which wind outwards from a central area and cross axes infinitely many times. One of the most familiar types of spirals is the Archimedean spiral, characterized in polar coordinates by its radius being a linear function of the polar angle (r = k θ). Other types include the logarithmic spiral, in which the radius is proportional to the exponential of a multiple of the polar angle (r = a ek θ), exemplified by the shell of the nautilus.

The cardioid, whose name references its heart-shaped appearance, can be defined similarly to the cycloid (see above) except that the circle now rolls around another identical circle. The cardioid has a cusp where the point on the former circle meets the latter circle. A cardioid generated from circles of radius a, and with its cusp at θ = 0, is given by the polar equation r = 2 a (1 − cos θ).

The lima¸on, whose name comes from a French term for “snail,” was described by Étienne Pascal, the father of Blaise Pascal. It is defined similarly to the cardioid, except that the point can now lie anywhere within the outer circle. Depending on their parameters, lima¸ons can have a cardioid-like “dimple” or an inner loop formed by the curve intersecting itself.

Lemniscates are a class of curves with a figure-8 shape. The infinity symbol is a lemniscate. There are several types of lemniscates, including the lemniscate of Booth, which is a special case of the hippopede, and the lemniscate of Bernoulli, along which the product of a point’s distances to two foci is constant. Its name comes from the Greek for “ribbon.”

title: Plagues And Pandemics
content:
The Great Plague of Athens struck Greece in 430 BC, during the Peloponnesian War. According to the historian Thucydides, the disease spread to Athens from Ethiopia and killed up to 25% of the city’s population, including its leading statesman, Pericles. Though the illness spread to other cities, its particular impact on Athens helped Sparta become the foremost city in Greece. The cause of the plague remains unknown; historians have speculated that it may have been typhus or an unknown type of hemorrhagic fever.

The Antonine Plague spread across the Roman Empire from AD 165 to 180. Roman troops brought the disease into the Mediterranean world after returning from war against Parthia in Mesopotamia. The outbreak is named for the Antonine dynasty, which ruled Rome at the time under co-emperors Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus (the latter of whom likely died of the plague); the dynasty’s founder, Antoninus Pius, had died in AD 161. The physician Galen wrote detailed accounts of the outbreak, which allowed modern scholars to determine that the plague was likely either smallpox or measles.

The Plague of Justinian is a common name for the first plague pandemic that swept Europe and Asia beginning during the 540s. The plague struck Constantinople during the reign of Justinian I, who was attempting to reassert Roman control over the Mediterranean. It was caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, the same agent that later caused the Black Death. The plague and its many recurrences devastated Byzantium and neighboring countries like the Sassanid Empire; their weakened states helped enable the Muslim conquests in the 7th century.

The Black Death is a common name for the second plague pandemic which spread in the mid-14th century. Mongol forces likely introduced the plague to Europe while besieging the Genoese colony of Kaffa in Crimea. Over the following decade, the disease killed roughly half of the continent’s population. It also sparked major social disruptions, including peasant revolts in England and France and mass anti-semitism, due to many blaming the plague on Jews. The frame story for Giovanni Boccaccio’s Decameron involves ten people fleeing the plague in Florence. Scattered plague outbreaks continued across Europe for the next 300 years, including the Great Plague of London in 1665. It is likely the deadliest pandemic ever.

Syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease, spread across Europe beginning in the 1490s. While its origins are disputed, many Renaissance and contemporary scholars believe it came to Europe from the Americas after Christopher Columbus’s voyages. It was first described among French troops invading Naples in 1495 and known then as the “great pox.” Syphilis remained a major public health threat in the western world until the introduction of penicillin in the 1940s. In the 20th century, the U.S. government conducted a study in Tuskegee, Alabama that involved intentionally and inhumanely not treating hundreds of Black men infected with the disease.

Typhus, an infectious fever carried by lice, spread across Europe in the late 1400s. While it may have been responsible for ancient pandemics, typhus was first conclusively identified among Spanish troops attacking Granada near the end of the Reconquista (15th century). Later typhus epidemics often coincided with military conflicts, for instance, causing most of the deaths during the Thirty Years’ War and Napoleon’s invasion of Russia. Typhus killed many victims of the Holocaust, including Anne Frank.

Smallpox, a disease caused by the variola virus, circulated as early as 1500 BC. While the disease became endemic across Europe and Asia, it caused devastation when introduced to new populations. Smallpox came to the Americas through Spanish conquistadors, causing millions of deaths among indigenous civilizations like the Aztecs and Incas. Later colonial efforts caused the disease to reach and decimate Aboriginal Australians and other native peoples. Chinese doctors developed strategies for inoculating against smallpox in the 1500s, while Edward Jenner created the first ever vaccine to prevent it in 1796 using the similar cowpox virus. A successful 20th-century campaign by the World Health organization led to the eradication of smallpox in 1980.

Cholera is an intestinal infection that originated in India. Largely as a consequence of British colonialism, cholera swept the globe during six pandemics in the 19th century. In the U.S. the disease killed former president James Polk and caused many deaths along the Oregon Trail. While studying cholera in London, epidemiologist John Snow recognized the Broad Street pump as the common link in an outbreak and concluded that the disease was water-borne. Though now less fatal due to available treatments, cholera persists in large parts of the world; it killed over 10,000 people during a 2010s outbreak in Haiti.

The Spanish Flu pandemic killed up to 100 million people from 1918 to 1920. Caused by the H1N1 strain of influenza, the disease was first documented in a U.S. army camp in Kansas. It acquired its misleading name because Spain was one of the few countries not to censor information about it amid World War I, a conflict that drove the disease’s spread. Because Spanish flu often caused cytokine storms in its victims, it disproportionately affected younger people. Notable victims of the pandemic included Gustav Klimt and Max Weber.

AIDS, a condition caused by HIV (the human immunodeficiency virus), triggered a pandemic beginning in 1981. Originating in monkeys, the virus jumped to humans in the early 20th century but did not spread widely until decades later. It is primarily sexually transmitted and devastated gay communities across the world in the 1980s and ’90s, largely due to intentional government inaction. The AIDS epidemic has also devastated sub-Saharan Africa; a 2013 study estimated that nearly 80% of all people currently living with HIV were from southern Africa. Gay journalist Randy Shilts chronicled the early pandemic and government indifference in his book And the Band Played On; he later died of AIDS himself. Public awareness of HIV/AIDS increased as it killed celebrities like Rock Hudson.
